newsitem.title: USA: US economy not wounded by GM Canada strike - experts.
newsitem.headline: US economy not wounded by GM Canada strike - experts.

text.p: The end of the Canadian Auto Workers strike against General Motors Corp after only 19 days means the work stoppage had only a minor impact on the U.S. economy, economists said on Tuesday.
Canadian industrial production will be severely hurt by the strike, but "U.S. figures won't be anywhere near there." said David Sloan, economist at consulting firm I.D.E.A.
"It looks as if U.S. auto sales and output will be adversely affected in late October and possibly early November by this strike," Sloan said.
"We'll see some slightly weak auto sales and industrial production figures for the U.S. in October," he added.

Earlier Tuesday, GM and the Canadian Auto Workers union said they had reached a tentative agreement to end the nearly three-week-old strike at GM's Canadian plants by 26,000 Canadian workers. The strike also idled as many as 19,931 GM workers in the United States and Mexico, GM said on Tuesday.
The agreement included a pledge by GM to limit sub-contracting, or outsourcing, and the sale of facilities.
The union conceded that GM's business plan might require it to deviate from an agreement reached in September with Chrysler Corp. that was intended to set an industry pattern.

James Glassman, senior economist at Chase Securities, said the number of people laid off in the U.S. as a result of the Canadian work stoppage was "too small to have much of an effect on anything other than a few weeks of jobless claims."

"There should be only limited, transitory effects on the initial (jobless) claims (data) and October payroll reports and no direct effect on the November payroll report," agreed analysts at MMS International.
Glassman said the strike probably swelled the number of new claims for state unemployment insurance in the latest week by five or six thousand.
New jobless claims totaled 340,000 in the week ended October 12.
Glassman said it is difficult to disentangle claims filed because of the GM strike from other claims.
"GM facilities are all over the place," he noted.
The impact on the October employment report will also be limited because the Labor Department conducted the workweek survey in the pay period that included October 12.
"Not many GM workers were idle then," said Glassman. "Things didn't really deteriorate until last week."
One aspect of the October employment report, the length of the average workweek, might be affected.
"The number of hours logged may have been depressed a little," said Glassman. "These autoworkers work a lot of overtime."
On the other hand, he said, "We're only talking about 10,000 workers in that period so on average, it might not be that big a deal."
"The negative impact on October payrolls will be overwhelmed by the bounce from September's payroll job decline," said Sloan who estimates non-farm payrolls will grow by 200,000 jobs in October.
"It took a bit of time for U.S. plants to be impacted (by the 19-day Canadian strike)," said Slaon. "Most of the U.S. plant layoffs came after the payroll survey."
Slaon said the strike could adversely impact the number of hours worked -- but just in the manufacturing sector.
"I don't think the strike will be a huge factor for U.S. data," said Sloan. "It will probably be a minor factor."
